11224Structural ChemistryComputational and Experimental Studies of Chemical and Biological SystemsStruct Chem1040-04001572-9001Kluwer Academic Publishers-Plenum PublishersNew Yorks11224-006-9010-8901010.1007/s11224-006-9010-8Original PaperA novel three-dimensional malonate-bridged complex {[Cu4(4,4′- bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}nWangXu-Da1LiangMao1LiLi-Cun12cJiangZong-Hui1LiaoDai-Zheng1YanShi-Ping1ChengPeng1grid.216938.70000000098787032Department of ChemistryNankai University300071TianjinP. R. Chinagrid.9227.e0000000119573309State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of MatterChinese Academy of Sciences350002FuzhouP. R. Chinallicun@nankai.edu.cn9120072200718158172200611320052512006912007© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 20062006Abstract

A novel malonate-bridged copper (II) compound of formula {[Cu4(4,4′-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n (4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; mal = malonate dianion) has been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. This compound exhibits a novel three-dimensional network being composed of Cu-4,4′-bipyridine layers which are pillared by malonate bridge ligands. The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment.

KeywordsCrystal structureThree-dimensionalCopper complexMalonatevolume-issue-count6issue-article-count18issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2007article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2006article-registration-date-month2article-registration-date-day17article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11224_2006_Article_9010.pdfoutput-mediumOnlinetarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2007issue-online-date-month1issue-online-date-day31issue-print-date-year2007issue-print-date-month1issue-print-date-day31issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryTheoretical and Computational Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryComputer Applications in Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

Metal coordination polymers with one-, two-, and three- dimensional frameworks have been the subject of intensive research for several decades. The structural design or modification of frameworks has become a very active field of the crystal engineering. An example of the advance in this field is the generation of polymeric structures in metal complexes using di-carboxylate ligands, which develop theoretical models of the exchange interaction in extended lattices [1]. The malonate ligand, with two neighbouring carboxylate groups, is a very flexible bridging ligand [2–7], because it can adopt several chelating bidentate coordination modes (bidentate chelation, bidentate chelation-unidentate, bidentate chelation-bis (unidentate)) and different carboxylato-bridging coordination modes (syn–syn, syn–anti, and anti–anti) [6]. On the other hand, the malonate ligand occupies one or two coordination positions, allowing the inclusion of other ligands in the coordination sphere of the metal. Thus, combining the malonate with other bridging ligands, monomers, dimers [8], trimers [9, 10], infinite chains [11, 12], 2D and 3D [13] complexes have been obtained and studied. Based on the reason, a motivation for design and synthesis of novel malonate-bridged metal frameworks has been raised. In this communication, We report the synthesis, structure of a novel 3D complex of formula {[Cu4(4,4′-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n.

Experimental

All starting materials were analytical reagents from commercial sources. Disodium malonate was abtained by direct reaction of malonic acid with sodium hydroxide in aqueous solution. IR spectra were recorded in KBr disks on a Shimadzu IR-408 infrared spectrophotometer in the 400–4000 cm−1 region. The electronic spectrum was measured with a Jasco-570 spectrophotometer.

{[Cu<sub>4</sub>(4,4´-bpy)<sub>8</sub>(mal)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>N</sub>

An aqueous solution (5 mL) of disodium malonate (0.118 g, 0.8 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of CuNO3·3H2O (0.484 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) with constant stirring for 30 min, and then a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 4,4′- bipyridine (0.0768 g, 0.4 mmol) was added slowly and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h, The solution was filtered and then evaporated slowly in air, blue single crystals were obtained after several days.

X-ray crystallography

Single crystal of the complex was mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromated MoKα radiation source (λ=0.71073 Å). Data collection was performed at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 program [13] and refined with SHELXS-97 [14] by full matrix least-squares method on F2. Further details of the structural analyses are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and bond angles are given in Table 2.

Results and discussionI.r. spectra

The IR spectra of this compound show broad band in the region 3100–3400 cm−1, which can be assigned to the strectching vibrations, υ(O–H), of the hydroxyl group in the water molecules. The ionic ClO4− anion show strong band at 1100 cm−1. The malonate shows strong υas(OCO) band at 1610 cm−1 and υs(OCO) band at 1419 cm−1. The strong bands at 1498, 1382, and 1227 cm−1 are due to the ring stretching of the coordinated 4,4′- bipyridine molecules.

Electronic spectra

The visible spectra were measured in the 400–1000 nm range in DMSO (Fig. 1). The spectra show a weak broad absorption centered at 767 nm, which analysed into three bands at 685 nm (υ1,ɛ=66 L mol−1 cm−1), 772 nm (υ2,ɛ=13 L mol−1 cm−1) and 898 nm (υ3,ɛ=102 L mol−1 cm−1) through Gaussian and non-linear curve fitting. They are attributed to the electronic transitions υ1:2B1g→2E1, υ2:2B1g→2B2g and υ3: 2B1g→2A1g.This spectrum is typical d-d transitions of copper(II) ions in a distorted octahedral symmetry environment.

Crystal structure

The X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that the complex has a three-dimensional structure involving square layers of 4,4′-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) ions growing in the ab plane, which are linked through malonate ligand.

The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2 with the atom-labeling scheme. In this complex, The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment. The Cu1 has a distorted octahedral coordination environment. The equatorial positions of Cu1 are occupied by N3, N4, N7b, N8a from four 4,4′-bipyridine groups with Cu1–N distances ranging from 2.067 to 2.089 Å, the trans-axial positions are occupied by the O3 and O4c [Cu1–O3, 2.349(8) Å; Cu1–O4c, 2.289(9) Å] of two malonate ligands. The Cu2 exhibits a distorted rhombus geometry. The two oxygens [Cu2–O1, 1.906(6) Å; Cu2–O2, 1.923(6) Å] from a malonate ligand and two nitrogen atoms [Cu2–N1, 2.011(10) Å; Cu2–N2, 2.015(8) Å] from two 4,4′-bipyridine ligands, The Cu1 atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4′-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. The Cu2 atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The bond angles between the ligands and the Cu1 centres range from 85.7(3)° to 94.3(2)°; while the corresponding angles for Cu2 range from 87.5(3)° to 93.6(3)°.

The layer structure features a square network as shown in Fig. 3, each bis(monodentate) 4,4′-bipyridine links two adjacent hexe-connected Cu atoms and every four metal centers are interconnected to form a planar square of 11.237×11.237 Å in the ab-plane. Finally, adjacent layers are linked by the malonate ligand as molecular pillars to furnish a 3D framework (Fig. 4). In this complex, Each malonate ligand links three copper atoms, acting as both bidentate chelate and bis(unidentate) and its carboxylate bridge (Cu2–O1–C43–O3–Cu1 and Cu2–O2–C41–O4–Cu1B) adopts the anti-syn conformation. Thus, the malonate group towards copper atoms, leading to a zig-zag chain. The Cu–Cu distances are 5.611 Å (Cu2···Cu1) and 5.630 Å (Cu2···Cu1B), whereas the distance of adjacent layers (Cu1-mal-Cu1B) is 9.275 Å. The 3D topological architecture is shown in Fig. 5. Each hexe-connected Cu atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4′-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. Each tetra-connected Cu atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The layer structure involve small planar squares with Cu atoms at each corner and Cu atom of adjacent two layers are connected by malonate in syn–anti mode.

We compare this compound with that previously reported of the complexes [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4′-bpy)].H2O (1) [15] and [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4′-bpy)] (2) [16] . Both compound 1 and 2 have a 2D square grid network structure and the malonate adopts both bidentate and unidentate coordination modes. For the present complex, there are two different points from compounds 1 and 2, (i) This compound has a novel three-dimensional framework, each layer containing planar squares of 4,4′-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) units and the adjacent layers are connected by malonate ligand. (ii) the malonate as a bridged ligand has its unusual structural role, it adopts both bidentate and bis(unidentate) coordination modes to forming one-dimensional chain. Our studies on the coordinating ability of the malonate dianion show that its great versatility as a ligand allow the construction of extended networks with different topologies which are dependent on the coordination geometry of the metal ion and other complementary ligands.

Supplementary materials

Further details on the crystal structure investigation may be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK) On quoting the depository No. CCDC 238294.

Acknowledgement

This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 20471031, 20471032).

elements.content: A novel malonate-bridged copper (II) compound of formula {[Cu4(4,4′-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n (4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; mal = malonate dianion) has been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. This compound exhibits a novel three-dimensional network being composed of Cu-4,4′-bipyridine layers which are pillared by malonate bridge ligands. The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel malonate-bridged copper (II) compound of formula {[Cu4(4,4'-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n (4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine; mal = malonate dianion) has been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. This compound exhibits a novel three-dimensional network being composed of Cu-4,4'-bipyridine layers which are pillared by malonate bridge ligands. The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment.

The structural design or modification of frameworks has become a very active field of the crystal engineering. An example of the advance in this field is the generation of polymeric structures in metal complexes using di-carboxylate ligands, which develop theoretical models of the exchange interaction in extended lattices [1]. The malonate ligand, with two neighbouring carboxylate groups, is a very flexible bridging ligand [2–7], because it can adopt several chelating bidentate coordination modes (bidentate chelation, bidentate chelation-unidentate, bidentate chelation-bis (unidentate)) and different carboxylato-bridging coordination modes (syn–syn, syn–anti, and anti–anti) [6]. On the other hand, the malonate ligand occupies one or two coordination positions, allowing the inclusion of other ligands in the coordination sphere of the metal. Thus, combining the malonate with other bridging ligands, monomers, dimers [8], trimers [9, 10], infinite chains [11, 12], 2D and 3D [13] complexes have been obtained and studied. Based on the reason, a motivation for design and synthesis of novel malonate-bridged metal frameworks has been raised. In this communication, We report the synthesis, structure of a novel 3D complex of formula {[Cu4(4,4′-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

 Metal coordination polymers with one-, two-, and three- dimensional frameworks have been the subject of intensive research for several decades. The structural design or modification of frameworks has become a very active field of the crystal engineering. An example of the advance in this field is the generation of polymeric structures in metal complexes using di-carboxylate ligands, which develop theoretical models of the exchange interaction in extended lattices [1]. The malonate ligand, with two neighbouring carboxylate groups, is a very flexible bridging ligand [2-7], because it can adopt several chelating bidentate coordination modes (bidentate chelation, bidentate chelation-unidentate, bidentate chelation-bis (unidentate)) and different carboxylato-bridging coordination modes (syn-syn, syn-anti, and anti-anti) [6]. On the other hand, the malonate ligand occupies one or two coordination positions, allowing the inclusion of other ligands in the coordination sphere of the metal. Thus, combining the malonate with other bridging ligands, monomers, dimers [8], trimers [9, 10], infinite chains [11, 12], 2D and 3D [13] complexes have been obtained and studied. Based on the reason, a motivation for design and synthesis of novel malonate-bridged metal frameworks has been raised. In this communication, We report the synthesis, structure of a novel 3D complex of formula {[Cu4(4,4'-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}n.

elements.content: All starting materials were analytical reagents from commercial sources. Disodium malonate was abtained by direct reaction of malonic acid with sodium hydroxide in aqueous solution. IR spectra were recorded in KBr disks on a Shimadzu IR-408 infrared spectrophotometer in the 400–4000 cm−1 region. The electronic spectrum was measured with a Jasco-570 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All starting materials were analytical reagents from commercial sources. Disodium malonate was abtained by direct reaction of malonic acid with sodium hydroxide in aqueous solution. IR spectra were recorded in KBr disks on a Shimadzu IR-408 infrared spectrophotometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. The electronic spectrum was measured with a Jasco-570 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (5 mL) of disodium malonate (0.118 g, 0.8 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of CuNO3·3H2O (0.484 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) with constant stirring for 30 min, and then a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 4,4′- bipyridine (0.0768 g, 0.4 mmol) was added slowly and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h, The solution was filtered and then evaporated slowly in air, blue single crystals were obtained after several days.
elements.clean_text:
{[Cu4(4,4´-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4(CH3OH)2}N

An aqueous solution (5 mL) of disodium malonate (0.118 g, 0.8 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of CuNO3⋅3H2O (0.484 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) with constant stirring for 30 min, and then a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 4,4'- bipyridine (0.0768 g, 0.4 mmol) was added slowly and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h, The solution was filtered and then evaporated slowly in air, blue single crystals were obtained after several days.

elements.content: Single crystal of the complex was mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromated MoKα radiation source (λ=0.71073 Å). Data collection was performed at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 program [13] and refined with SHELXS-97 [14] by full matrix least-squares method on F2. Further details of the structural analyses are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and bond angles are given in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single crystal of the complex was mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromated MoKα radiation source (λ=0.71073 Å). Data collection was performed at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 program [13] and refined with SHELXS-97 [14] by full matrix least-squares method on F2. Further details of the structural analyses are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond distances and bond angles are given in Table 2.

The IR spectra of this compound show broad band in the region 3100–3400 cm−1, which can be assigned to the strectching vibrations, υ(O–H), of the hydroxyl group in the water molecules. The ionic ClO4− anion show strong band at 1100 cm−1. The malonate shows strong υas(OCO) band at 1610 cm−1 and υs(OCO) band at 1419 cm−1. The strong bands at 1498, 1382, and 1227 cm−1 are due to the ring stretching of the coordinated 4,4′- bipyridine molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

I.r. spectra

The IR spectra of this compound show broad band in the region 3100-3400 cm-1, which can be assigned to the strectching vibrations, υ(O-H), of the hydroxyl group in the water molecules. The ionic ClO4- anion show strong band at 1100 cm-1. The malonate shows strong υas(OCO) band at 1610 cm-1 and υs(OCO) band at 1419 cm-1. The strong bands at 1498, 1382, and 1227 cm-1 are due to the ring stretching of the coordinated 4,4'- bipyridine molecules.

elements.content: The Electronic spectra of {[Cu4(4,4′-bpy)8(mal)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(H2O)4–CH3OH)2}n

The visible spectra were measured in the 400–1000 nm range in DMSO (Fig. 1). The spectra show a weak broad absorption centered at 767 nm, which analysed into three bands at 685 nm (υ1,ɛ=66 L mol−1 cm−1), 772 nm (υ2,ɛ=13 L mol−1 cm−1) and 898 nm (υ3,ɛ=102 L mol−1 cm−1) through Gaussian and non-linear curve fitting. They are attributed to the electronic transitions υ1:2B1g→2E1, υ2:2B1g→2B2g and υ3: 2B1g→2A1g.This spectrum is typical d-d transitions of copper(II) ions in a distorted octahedral symmetry environment.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic spectra

The visible spectra were measured in the 400-1000 nm range in DMSO (Fig. 1). The spectra show a weak broad absorption centered at 767 nm, which analysed into three bands at 685 nm (υ1,ɛ=66 L mol-1 cm-1), 772 nm (υ2,ɛ=13 L mol-1 cm-1) and 898 nm (υ3,ɛ=102 L mol-1 cm-1) through Gaussian and non-linear curve fitting. They are attributed to the electronic transitions υ1:2B1g→2E1, υ2:2B1g→2B2g and υ3: 2B1g→2A1g.This spectrum is typical d-d transitions of copper(II) ions in a distorted octahedral symmetry environment.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that the complex has a three-dimensional structure involving square layers of 4,4′-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) ions growing in the ab plane, which are linked through malonate ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure

The X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that the complex has a three-dimensional structure involving square layers of 4,4'-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) ions growing in the ab plane, which are linked through malonate ligand.

elements.content: The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2 with the atom-labeling scheme. In this complex, The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment. The Cu1 has a distorted octahedral coordination environment. The equatorial positions of Cu1 are occupied by N3, N4, N7b, N8a from four 4,4′-bipyridine groups with Cu1–N distances ranging from 2.067 to 2.089 Å, the trans-axial positions are occupied by the O3 and O4c [Cu1–O3, 2.349(8) Å; Cu1–O4c, 2.289(9) Å] of two malonate ligands. The Cu2 exhibits a distorted rhombus geometry. The two oxygens [Cu2–O1, 1.906(6) Å; Cu2–O2, 1.923(6) Å] from a malonate ligand and two nitrogen atoms [Cu2–N1, 2.011(10) Å; Cu2–N2, 2.015(8) Å] from two 4,4′-bipyridine ligands, The Cu1 atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4′-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. The Cu2 atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The bond angles between the ligands and the Cu1 centres range from 85.7(3)° to 94.3(2)°; while the corresponding angles for Cu2 range from 87.5(3)° to 93.6(3)°.
elements.clean_text: The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2 with the atom-labeling scheme. In this complex, The copper(II) ions has two different coordination environment. The Cu1 has a distorted octahedral coordination environment. The equatorial positions of Cu1 are occupied by N3, N4, N7b, N8a from four 4,4'-bipyridine groups with Cu1-N distances ranging from 2.067  to 2.089 Å, the trans-axial positions are occupied by the O3 and O4c [Cu1-O3, 2.349(8) Å; Cu1-O4c, 2.289(9) Å] of two malonate ligands. The Cu2 exhibits a distorted rhombus geometry. The two oxygens [Cu2-O1, 1.906(6) Å; Cu2-O2, 1.923(6) Å] from a malonate ligand and two nitrogen atoms [Cu2-N1, 2.011(10) Å; Cu2-N2, 2.015(8) Å] from two 4,4'-bipyridine ligands, The Cu1 atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4'-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. The Cu2 atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The bond angles between the ligands and the Cu1 centres range from 85.7(3)° to 94.3(2)°; while the corresponding angles for Cu2 range from 87.5(3)° to 93.6(3)°.

elements.content: The adjacent Cu-4,4′-bipyridine layers are linked by the malonate ligand as molecular pillars to furnish a 3D framework
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4The adjacent Cu-4,4'-bipyridine layers are linked by the malonate ligand as molecular pillars to furnish a 3D framework

elements.content: The layer structure features a square network as shown in Fig. 3, each bis(monodentate) 4,4′-bipyridine links two adjacent hexe-connected Cu atoms and every four metal centers are interconnected to form a planar square of 11.237×11.237 Å in the ab-plane. Finally, adjacent layers are linked by the malonate ligand as molecular pillars to furnish a 3D framework (Fig. 4). In this complex, Each malonate ligand links three copper atoms, acting as both bidentate chelate and bis(unidentate) and its carboxylate bridge (Cu2–O1–C43–O3–Cu1 and Cu2–O2–C41–O4–Cu1B) adopts the anti-syn conformation. Thus, the malonate group towards copper atoms, leading to a zig-zag chain. The Cu–Cu distances are 5.611 Å (Cu2···Cu1) and 5.630 Å (Cu2···Cu1B), whereas the distance of adjacent layers (Cu1-mal-Cu1B) is 9.275 Å. The 3D topological architecture is shown in Fig. 5. Each hexe-connected Cu atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4′-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. Each tetra-connected Cu atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The layer structure involve small planar squares with Cu atoms at each corner and Cu atom of adjacent two layers are connected by malonate in syn–anti mode.
elements.clean_text: The layer structure features a square network as shown in Fig. 3, each bis(monodentate) 4,4'-bipyridine links two adjacent hexe-connected Cu atoms and every four metal centers are interconnected to form a planar square of 11.237×11.237 Å in the ab-plane. Finally, adjacent layers are linked by the malonate ligand as molecular pillars to furnish a 3D framework (Fig. 4). In this complex, Each malonate ligand links three copper atoms, acting as both bidentate chelate and bis(unidentate) and its carboxylate bridge (Cu2-O1-C43-O3-Cu1 and Cu2-O2-C41-O4-Cu1B) adopts the anti-syn conformation. Thus, the malonate group towards copper atoms, leading to a zig-zag chain. The Cu-Cu distances are 5.611 Å (Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu1) and 5.630 Å (Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu1B), whereas the distance of adjacent layers (Cu1-mal-Cu1B) is 9.275 Å. The 3D topological architecture is shown in Fig. 5. Each hexe-connected Cu atom is bridged to four Cu atoms by 4,4'-bipyridine and two Cu atoms by malonate. Each tetra-connected Cu atom is bridged to two Cu atoms by malonate. The layer structure involve small planar squares with Cu atoms at each corner and Cu atom of adjacent two layers are connected by malonate in syn-anti mode.

elements.content: We compare this compound with that previously reported of the complexes [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4′-bpy)].H2O (1) [15] and [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4′-bpy)] (2) [16] . Both compound 1 and 2 have a 2D square grid network structure and the malonate adopts both bidentate and unidentate coordination modes. For the present complex, there are two different points from compounds 1 and 2, (i) This compound has a novel three-dimensional framework, each layer containing planar squares of 4,4′-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) units and the adjacent layers are connected by malonate ligand. (ii) the malonate as a bridged ligand has its unusual structural role, it adopts both bidentate and bis(unidentate) coordination modes to forming one-dimensional chain. Our studies on the coordinating ability of the malonate dianion show that its great versatility as a ligand allow the construction of extended networks with different topologies which are dependent on the coordination geometry of the metal ion and other complementary ligands.
elements.clean_text: We compare this compound with that previously reported of the complexes [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4'-bpy)].H2O (1) [15] and [Cu2(mal)2(H2O)2(4,4'-bpy)] (2) [16] . Both compound 1 and 2 have a 2D square grid network structure and the malonate adopts both bidentate and unidentate coordination modes. For the present complex, there are two different points from compounds 1 and 2, (i) This compound has a novel three-dimensional framework, each layer containing planar squares of 4,4'-bipyridine-bridged copper(II) units and the adjacent layers are connected by malonate ligand. (ii) the malonate as a bridged ligand has its unusual structural role, it adopts both bidentate and bis(unidentate) coordination modes to forming one-dimensional chain. Our studies on the coordinating ability of the malonate dianion show that its great versatility as a ligand allow the construction of extended networks with different topologies which are dependent on the coordination geometry of the metal ion and other complementary ligands.
